importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: President Kais Saied seized extraordinary powers in 2021, marking a turning point in Tunisia's political landscape and setting the stage for increased public unrest over governance and environmental degradation.
A government pledge in 2017 to phase out the CGT phosphate plant was broken, leading to sustained public anger and contributing to the current environmental and political crisis.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The recent wave of protests and strikes in Gabes began in early 2025, culminating in a full general strike on October 21, 2025, highlighting ongoing environmental and political tensions.

keyTakeAways: A general strike in Gabes, Tunisia, on October 21, 2025, shut down shops, schools, markets, and cafes, driven by public outrage over pollution from a state-run chemical plant.
The CGT phosphate plant, opened in 1972, is blamed by residents and activists for severe environmental degradation, including gas poisoning, cancer cases, and marine life collapse.

Residents and environmental activists claim that radioactive waste and phosphogypsum are being released into the sea and air, with over 200 people hospitalized in recent weeks for respiratory distress.
The UGTT labour union led the protests, with its secretary-general Sami Al-Tahiri stating that the strike succeeded across all social segments and that further protests and mass rallies are planned.
Despite a 2017 government commitment to phase out the plant, authorities have instead increased production, calling phosphate a 'pillar of the national economy'.
President Kais Saied has described the pollution as an 'environmental assassination' and blamed past administrations for health crises and ecosystem destruction.
Chinese companies have been brought in to help mitigate gas emissions and prevent further environmental dumping into the Mediterranean Sea.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A general strike in Gabes, Tunisia, on October 21, 2025, has brought the city to a standstill as tens of thousands protest against the environmental and health damage caused by the state-run CGT phosphate plant. Residents, led by the powerful UGTT labor union, blame the plant—operating since 1972—for widespread pollution, including gas poisoning, cancer, and marine ecosystem collapse. Over 200 people have been hospitalized, and activists claim that even local food has been poisoned. Despite a 2017 pledge to shut down the plant, authorities have instead increased production, calling phosphate vital to the national economy. President Kais Saied has framed the crisis as an 'environmental assassination,' while protesters demand immediate shutdown and accountability. In response, Chinese companies have been brought in to mitigate emissions, and the UGTT has declared plans for further mass protests.
title: General strike shuts down Tunisia’s Gabes over pollution crisis
